ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: As opposed to microeconomics, we learned more about concepts that have direct applications in the real world. Calculating GDP, Solow growth model, aggregate supply and demand, finance, inflation, trade policy, monetary policy, debt, inflation, etc.
I gained basic concepts in trade, supply and demand, supply and labor, GDP, and other macroeconomic calculations.
learned a lot about how the economy functions, banks work, taxes, inflation, etc.
I learned a lot about the way trade, labor, and production affect the economy. I also have gained a much better understanding of politics and the media.
What you would expect. Learned more applicable things than micro.
I gained an understanding of introductory macroeconomic models and a broad overview of monetary and fiscal policy.
General understanding of how the economy works and the understanding of topics like inflation.
I was able to critically think and evaluate macroeconomic principles in real world contexts.
Learned introductory macroeconomics
You learn basic macro ideas.
I developed a general knowledge of the ideas of macroeconomics and all the associated formulas.
basic macroeconomics skills
i learned about the macroeconomy and how that relates to lots of important institutions that we read about in the news
Foundations of macroeconomics and became a more informed consumer of economic news.
Econ and how to navigate it on a macro scale.
Foundational concepts in macroeconomics, solow model, trade, etc.
A great foundational course about Macroeconomics, applied to real life topics as well.
I gained a broad and thorough understanding of macroeconomics.
I really enjoyed this course because it felt applicable to trends seen in real life. I also liked that it included a lot of real world data.
Macroeconomics.
Learned lots about macroeconomics

-Critical thinking skills about macroeconomic issues
-Analysis at a high level of trends
-Learn about the foundations of finance and the monetary system including interest rates
-Learn how the government impacts the economy

In this course, I learned about how the economy functions as a whole, how it moves and functions. We did a lot of modeling of economic situations, from the Solow model to the Aggregate Supply/Demand model, to the Flow/Intertemporal Budget Constraints, and discussed real-world trends in the past and present.
Macroeconomic policy

I was impressed by how much we covered in this course. We learned about GDP, how to grow GDP (Solow model), the labor market, stocks and bonds, aggregate supply and demand, unemployment, taxes, measuring economic inequality, and more.
I learned general knowledge about macroeconomics! A quality introduction into the field and how to complete its problems in a mathematical and quantitative way.
I learned about various selected models of macroeconomics and how economic growth and stability occurs through theoretical models.
Basic introductory macroeconomic concecpts.
Basics of macroeconomics and the foundational Econ knowledge to start understanding mechanisms like trade and inequality.
How to analyze macro economic trends with foundational theories
Application of knowledge outside of problem sets. Specifically for the second Professor.
intro macro
Learnt about financial markets, government policies, GDP, economies and many related information

From this class, I learned how to use economics in the real world. Skills I learned were how to use models to understand real world concepts involving GDP, aggregate demand, labor functions. The skills I used were the ability to take notes involving diagrams to help understand the topics of ECON 116.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: 

WILLIAM HAWKINS (the course coordinator, but held sections, office hours, and review sessions). He is INCREDIBLE. He keeps this class EXTREMELY organized, and he is always available for help. Go to his sections and office hours in my opinion, he often explained the material more concisely than the professors would in class. He is so engaging, and genuinely cares about helping his students learn. Whenever I asked a question on Ed Discussion, he would respond almost immediately. Dr. Hawkins is responsive and will always be there if you need his help. I can't express how much I loved him as a professor (I would say one of my best professors at Yale). 

Professor Zilibotti was a much better lecturer than Professor Moscarini. During the first half of the semester when Moscarini was teaching, I learned mostly from going to section, peer tutoring, and completing the PSETs rather than lecture. I would attribute this to his lecture style; while he was very knowledgable, he is soft-spoken and not very engaging. However, Professor Zilibotti in the second half of the semester was a lot clearer and I learned a lot from him (albeit, I still preferred Dr. Hawkin's style of teaching in section. It always helped).

I liked the worksheets before the PSETs, it helped to solidify/consolidate our knowledge before tackling the PSET.

The peer tutors were amazing!!! Shoutout to Grace and Mark.

Weaknesses: Maybe the lack of practice tests for the off-sequence curriculum, but this honestly wasn't really an issue because Dr. Hawkins told us which questions from each practice test were relevant.
I personally was not extremely interested in the course content, but the course was taught very well and with great detail.

Strengths: lots of office hours and resources
Weaknesses: some classes are not very engaging

strengths: super relevant information that directly applies to our world. very easy to see how this knowledge can be applied to everyday life
weaknesses: sometimes the class felt disorganized. needed more overarching "this is different from this because..." explanations
Strengths: very well organized and course director is fantastic. No suggestions for improvement.
It was pretty much what I expected.
The professors and TFs were very accessible and eager to help with any questions. However, often in-class instruction was unclear and the important synthesis of information was done individually.

The first half of the course is extremely boring but gets more interesting as you reach topics like inflation. Also, Dr. Hawkins is by far and above, the best part of the course. His lecture summaries are a godsend.
This course is very well taught with numerous digestible topics. I would love to have more intensive psets!

William Hawkins should be teaching this class. Having very senior people do the lectures results in disconnect between students and teacher. No one understood anything until they went to review sessions with Hawkins, which were super helpful. The whole time I thought Hawkins was the more senior person because of his amazing teaching and immense knowledge. He is definitely better at teaching the introductory stuff, and at times I felt like this course was more confusing and difficult than it had to be. Strengths: passionate lecturers. Weaknesses: the lecturers struggled to teach to undergraduates.

Strengths: consistent, professor fabrizio zilibotti 
Weaknesses: professor giuseppe moscarini, course director professor hawkins.

The general ideas of macroeconomics are extremely interesting and exciting. However, these ideas would only every so often shine through the clouds of complex math that compose most of the instruction in this course. I think it would be better if those ideas could be taught more clearly and all at once, and then be obscured by the formulas and derivations.

great course director and TAs and very detailed lectures

perhaps getting rid of "worksheets" and just making the psets more detailed

Strengths: generally interesting topics and relevant to real world. It was more social science than Econ 115, so it felt applicable to what was happening. 
Weaknesses: a lot of content and memorization required, but the worksheets and p-sets are great at solidifying learnings.
My TF was nice, but honestly I felt like I didnt learn a whole lot in my sections which I found frustrating.
It was very well delivered between Professors Moscarini and Zilibotti, and the way it was conducted vis--vis not releasing lecture recordings in the beginning was quite smart!

The wonderful peer tutors and the amount of separate tutoring opportunities for students was a huge strength. Unfortunately, the lectures and sections were not very helpful. Grace Miller in particular was incredibly helpful and contributed a great deal to my success in the course.

One strength of the course is that it is very structured -- each topic always came with an accompanying slide deck, problem set, and worksheet. One weakness of the course is that it would be cool to apply some of these topics and not just learn about them theoretically. I would also love more feedback about my progress and grade throughout the course.
Strengths - Information is laid out very well and the course doesn't feel rushed. Well structured for learning.

This course was very well-taught! Lectures were engaging and well-paced, and the Worksheets and Problem Sets really enhanced my learning. I appreciated that support was available whenever I needed it, whether through office hours or peer tutoring sessions. The class was also incredibly well-organizedI especially appreciated having access to the Ed Discussion Board.

I thought the sections and many office hours were very helpful

The course does go VERY fast and theres no time to even think about the material youre learning during the lecture. That makes it very difficult to follow along with the instructor builds on material taught in the same lecture because you have not had time to process it.
Struggled with memorizing formulas

-Strengths:
-Professors were knowledgeable and quite engaging
-Well structured curriculum, each subject guides nicely to the next
-Good out of class resources
-Lecture summaries and lecture slides available
Weaknesses:
-lecture volume, only twice a week, sometimes more volume could make more engaging with 3 classes of 50 minutes instead of 2 classes of 1:15 hrs

This course was very thorough, and I felt like I was always where I needed to be. The professors had a lot to say, and the material was very straightforward. Dr. Hawkins, my section leader, is my favorite instructor at Yale, as he makes things clear and is very understanding of what his students need.

However, there were times during this class where I found myself zoning out or getting bored. I would recommend including some examples that are relatable and/or entertaining, in order to keep the class engaged.

The course is extremely well organized. I appreciated how structured the discussion sections were, how many office hours were offered, and the effort Dr. Hawkins put into providing us lecture summaries. The worksheets were also quite helpful in internalizing the curriculum.
I think the TF and ULA office hours are the greatest strength of this class.

Strength: the content material was enlightening and interesting. Section with William Hawkins was great.
Weaknesses: many of the lectures felt slow and difficult to engage with.

I think real life examples are very valuable and important. Modern news, documentaries, and historical examples are great learning tools. This class used a few of them, but I think that it could benefit from more. The book is a massive strength and the worksheets.

The professors did not provide organized lectures and the content was a bit over the place in many instances. For instance, some material was never covered in class, but appeared in problem sets and the exam. The professors also did not do a good job of explaining concepts and it was to the student to find out through peer tutor hours and collaboration with peers. I think there needs to be more structure to the lectures for this course to get a better rating.
Very well organized with lots of resources available to get help and learn. I think the psets were fair and the worksheets were super helpful and I really liked their format.

Strengths include great teaching staff and peer tutors, most notably Grace Miller, William Hawkins, and Mitchell. One weakness was that there was not much material to practice studying for the last few sections of the class because previous exams did not test on this material. This material includes Taylor rule, inter temporal budget constraints, and inequality. A fix for this would be to create some extra practice questions before the final.
The second Professor did a much better job explaining and engaging.
I liked the weekly sections. One weakness was the policy of not recording classes. I think students would have benefitted better if the classes were recorded and the recordings released on time.

The strengths of this course is that the class was very informative. We received a lot of feedback on our assignments such as PSETS and worksheets. 
Weaknesses is that the sections were not as helpful as I thought they would be towards the exams.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, you learn a lot but you also have to put in the work to study and engage with the material.
Yes. Economics is another lens to look at the world through, and it helps you understand why institutions work the way that they do.
no
yes because i think every student should understand the concepts presented in this course.

I would definitely recommend this class to anyone. Everyone should understand the principles of macroeconomics in order to be able to follow current events and understand economic policy. Even if your major does not require this class, I would recommend taking it.
Sure but take it in the spring if you can. It's kind of weirdly taught in the fall, so I would say if you have the choice definitely take it in the spring instead.
Yea! Even if you're not an econ major, and are willing to take an exam-based course to learn about the general economy, I'd do it.
I would definitely recommend this to my other peers. Such understanding is fundamental in economic theory and is well taught.
I would recommend solely for people who are majoring in Econ or need it to take higher level classes.

i would not recommend this course unless you have to take it. it is obviously a class that attempts to weed out econ majors. however, not everybody who takes this class wants to major in econ and end up having to commit more time to this class than a class for their major.
Yes, I would. The course was very mathy and formula-driven, but the ideas of macroeconomics are very interesting.
i would, as lots of the content in the class is super relevant to not just econ but other subjects as well
Yes, if you're interested in macroeconomics and want a good overview of economic terms/concepts.
I would, but I think going to office hours is really helpful, so I would make sure you had space in your week for that
Only if they believe a macroeconomics background is important for their career.
Yes if you like a good introduction to macroeconomics.
Yes. It's an essential for anyone going into any type of social science.
I would highly recommend this course to another student, both because the material is fascinating and important to learn and because it is an extremely well-taught, highly engaging course.
Yes
Its macro, aint much to it. Wont make make or break your schedule. Learning about finance is good and fun
Yes, I thought I learned a lot and enjoyed it

I think this was a well-paced intro to macroeconomics. I would recommend this course to any Yale student interested in Econ. I dont think it is too difficult as well. The workload is not too intensive. I think it is a good and very interesting course!
If you are interested in the nuances of federal economic policy, I would recommend this course.
Yes if they like Econ
Yes, I would recommend this class to another student. I think knowing the basics of macroeconomics is important for everyone.
Yes, but mostly as a prereq/req.
Yes! If they hope to take later economic classes, this is a necessity.

Not unless you are an ECON, EPE, Global, or related major that requires the course. Take a first-year ECON seminar or a higher level ECON course to feel fulfilled and enjoy learning the material. Intro Macro with Moscarini/Zilibotti is not the best introduction to macroeconomics, in my opinion.
If you want to take an introductory course in macroeconomics, this is the one.
Yes if you are an econ major or similar majors.

Yes, I would recommend this class because I feel like I learned a lot of important information (like finance, how stocks and bonds work, how inflation works, etc). Even non-Econ majors should definitely take this class. It was definitely a class where if you put the work in you could receive a good grade.
Yes
loved the visiting prof zilibotti! he made econ very engaging. recommend taking with him.
Yes! I think it's a very good introduction to the macro economics world, away from just demand and supply. If you like thinking about things on a bigger scale, I'm sure you'd like it.
Yes because this course give you a base understanding of Economics if you are interested in studying this field.
